name: Markdown file
code: Linux and MacOS  , open terminal > navigator to the folder you want to save the file in > type ' touch filename.md ' > open the file in your favorite text editor and start writing your markdown code. Windows  , open command prompt > navigator to the folder you want to save the file in  > type ' echo.>filename.md '> open the file in your favorite text editor and start writing your markdown code.
explaination:
Markdown is a lightweight markup language for creating formatted text using a plain-text editor. John Gruber and Aaron Swartz created Markdown in 2004 as a markup language that is appealing to human readers in its source code form. Markdown is widely used in blogging, instant messaging, online forums, collaborative software, documentation pages, and readme files.
Read more

name: Heading
explaination: The code provided above creates an HTML element of 'h1', feel free the customize the code to meet your different prefferances to the  h2,h3,h4,h5,h6 ## Heading 2  ### Heading 3  #### Heading 4  ##### Heading 5  ###### Heading 6. Note that the number of '#' determines the size of the heading.

name: Link
explaination: The code provided above creates a link to a website, feel free to customize the code to meet your different prefferances by changing the text in the square brackets to your desired text and the link in the round brackets to your desired link.

name: Emphasis
explaination: You can use asterisks (*) or underscores (_) to create emphasis. One asterisk/underscore will create italic text, while two will create bold text.

name: Lists
code:
Unordered List:
- Item 1
- Item 2
- Subitem A
- Subitem B
Ordered List:
1. First item
2. Second item
3. Third item
explaination: Markdown supports both ordered and unordered lists. Use dashes (-) or asterisks (*) for unordered lists, and numbers for ordered lists.

name: Code Block
explaination: Use triple backticks (```) to create a code block. You can also specify the language for syntax highlighting after the opening triple backticks, as shown in the example.

name: Images
explaination: To display an image, use an exclamation mark (!), followed by the alt text in square brackets and the image URL in parentheses.

name: Blockquote
explaination: Use the greater-than symbol (>) followed by a space to create a blockquote. You can also nest blockquotes.

name: Task List
explaination: In GitHub-flavored Markdown, you can create task lists using square brackets with an 'x' for completed tasks and a space for incomplete tasks.

name: Tables
explaination: Create tables using vertical bars (|) to separate cells and hyphens (-) to create headers. The header row is separated from the content with a row of pipes.

name: Code Inline
explaination: To create inline code, enclose the code within backticks (`).

name: Strikethrough
explaination: Add two tildes (~~) before and after the text to create strikethrough.

name: Horizontal Rule
explaination: You can create a horizontal rule with three or more hyphens, asterisks, or underscores on a line by themselves.

name: Mentions
explaination: In GitHub-flavored Markdown, you can mention users or teams by using the @ symbol followed by the username.

name: Emoji
explaination: GitHub-flavored Markdown supports emojis. Use colons to enclose the emoji name.

name: Fenced Code Blocks
explaination: For code blocks with syntax highlighting, you can specify the language immediately after the opening triple backticks.

name: Links to Headings
explaination: You can create internal links to headings in the same document by using a hash symbol (#) followed by the heading text in lowercase, with spaces replaced by hyphens.

name: Footnotes
code:
Here is a sentence with a footnote[^1].

[^1]: This is the footnote content.
explaination: You can create footnotes using the caret symbol (^) followed by a unique identifier in square brackets. The footnote content is defined at the bottom of the document.

name: Autolinks
explaination: URLs and email addresses are automatically converted to clickable links in Markdown.

name: Strikethrough
explaination: To create strikethrough text, wrap the text with two tildes (~~).

name: Superscript and Subscript
explaination: You can create superscript using the  tag <sup> and subscript using the <sub> tag.

name: SHA-1 Hashes
explaination: GitHub-flavored Markdown recognizes and formats SHA-1 hashes as links to corresponding commits on GitHub repositories.

name: Issue References
explaination: GitHub-flavored Markdown will automatically create links to issues when you reference them using the `#` symbol followed by the issue number.

name: Mentioning Commits
explaination: When you reference a commit using its SHA-1 hash, GitHub-flavored Markdown will create a link to that commit in the repository.

name: Table of Contents
explaination: GitHub-flavored Markdown can generate a table of contents for your document by adding `[TOC]` at the desired location.

name: Issue and Pull Request References
explaination: GitHub-flavored Markdown allows you to reference issues and pull requests using the `#` symbol followed by the issue or PR number.
